trans-unit.source: Azure App Service gateway
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service gateway

trans-unit.source: Azure App Service offers built-in authentication services that implement [OAuth 2.0](#oauth) and [OpenID Connect](#oauth) and work with multiple *identity providers*.
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service offers built-in authentication services that implement [OAuth 2.0](#oauth) and [OpenID Connect](#oauth) and work with multiple *identity providers*.

trans-unit.source: An identity provider is an external service, trusted by Azure App Service, that authenticates your app's users.
trans-unit.target: An identity provider is an external service, trusted by Azure App Service, that authenticates your app's users.

trans-unit.source: App Service supports the most popular identity providers:
trans-unit.target: App Service supports the most popular identity providers:

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Account
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Account

trans-unit.source: Google
trans-unit.target: Google

trans-unit.source: Twitter
trans-unit.target: Twitter

trans-unit.source: Facebook
trans-unit.target: Facebook

trans-unit.source: Gateway architecture
trans-unit.target: Gateway architecture

trans-unit.source: Any Azure resource group that contains API apps or mobile apps includes a *gateway*.
trans-unit.target: Any Azure resource group that contains API apps or mobile apps includes a *gateway*.

trans-unit.source: The gateway is an Azure resource that runs in a web app and handles administrative tasks including authentication for API apps and mobile apps in the resource group.
trans-unit.target: The gateway is an Azure resource that runs in a web app and handles administrative tasks including authentication for API apps and mobile apps in the resource group.

trans-unit.source: The gateway handles login procedures, manages tokens, and prevents unauthenticated calls from reaching API apps that are [configured to require authenticated access](../app-service-api/app-service-api-dotnet-add-authentication.md#protect-the-api-app).
trans-unit.target: The gateway handles login procedures, manages tokens, and prevents unauthenticated calls from reaching API apps that are [configured to require authenticated access](../app-service-api/app-service-api-dotnet-add-authentication.md#protect-the-api-app).

trans-unit.source: The gateway can control access to API apps because all incoming HTTP requests destined for API apps in the resource group are routed through the gateway.
trans-unit.target: The gateway can control access to API apps because all incoming HTTP requests destined for API apps in the resource group are routed through the gateway.

trans-unit.source: The following diagram illustrates these gateway functions.
trans-unit.target: The following diagram illustrates these gateway functions.

trans-unit.source: Gateway features
trans-unit.target: Gateway features

trans-unit.source: The gateway authentication services offer several advantages over running your own implementation of OAuth 2.0:
trans-unit.target: The gateway authentication services offer several advantages over running your own implementation of OAuth 2.0:

trans-unit.source: Microsoft provides SDKs that enable you to perform authentication and authorization tasks using a simplified syntax.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft provides SDKs that enable you to perform authentication and authorization tasks using a simplified syntax.

trans-unit.source: Because App Service handles more authentication tasks, your development and testing time is minimized, and you avoid most or all of the impact of changes in provider implementations of OAuth.
trans-unit.target: Because App Service handles more authentication tasks, your development and testing time is minimized, and you avoid most or all of the impact of changes in provider implementations of OAuth.

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple applications to protect and you keep them in one resource group, you only need one client ID and client secret for each authentication provider, because there is only one redirect URL for the gateway.
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple applications to protect and you keep them in one resource group, you only need one client ID and client secret for each authentication provider, because there is only one redirect URL for the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Monitoring and troubleshooting are easier because you can monitor authentication-related traffic for an entire resource group by monitoring the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Monitoring and troubleshooting are easier because you can monitor authentication-related traffic for an entire resource group by monitoring the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Debugging is easier because you can configure a program to use the gateway while running in debug mode locally, and you don't have to change redirect URLs in your identity provider account.
trans-unit.target: Debugging is easier because you can configure a program to use the gateway while running in debug mode locally, and you don't have to change redirect URLs in your identity provider account.

trans-unit.source: Server flow vs. client flow
trans-unit.target: Server flow vs. client flow

trans-unit.source: The App Service gateway offers two ways to authenticate clients: *client flow* and *server flow*.
trans-unit.target: The App Service gateway offers two ways to authenticate clients: *client flow* and *server flow*.

trans-unit.source: In both flows, the client application sends the user credentials (typically, user name and password) directly to the identity provider.
trans-unit.target: In both flows, the client application sends the user credentials (typically, user name and password) directly to the identity provider.

trans-unit.source: Neither the gateway nor your application receives user credentials in either flow.
trans-unit.target: Neither the gateway nor your application receives user credentials in either flow.

trans-unit.source: Client flow
trans-unit.target: Client flow

trans-unit.source: Client flow means the client application communicates directly with the identity provider to get the provider's access token.
trans-unit.target: Client flow means the client application communicates directly with the identity provider to get the provider's access token.

trans-unit.source: The client application sends the provider's access token to the gateway.
trans-unit.target: The client application sends the provider's access token to the gateway.

trans-unit.source: The gateway creates and sends to the client a user context token.
trans-unit.target: The gateway creates and sends to the client a user context token.

trans-unit.source: This user context token is also known as a Zumo token, from the original code name for [Azure Mobile Services](/documentation/services/mobile-services/).
trans-unit.target: This user context token is also known as a Zumo token, from the original code name for [Azure Mobile Services](/documentation/services/mobile-services/).

trans-unit.source: (Authentication services for API Apps and Mobile Apps are built on the same architecture originally developed for Mobile Services.)
trans-unit.target: (Authentication services for API Apps and Mobile Apps are built on the same architecture originally developed for Mobile Services.)

trans-unit.source: The following diagram illustrates this flow.
trans-unit.target: The following diagram illustrates this flow.

trans-unit.source: The client then provides the Zumo token in HTTP requests when it calls protected API apps or mobile apps.
trans-unit.target: The client then provides the Zumo token in HTTP requests when it calls protected API apps or mobile apps.

trans-unit.source: The gateway stores the provider tokens and keeps track of which ones are associated with which Zumo tokens.
trans-unit.target: The gateway stores the provider tokens and keeps track of which ones are associated with which Zumo tokens.

trans-unit.source: Server flow
trans-unit.target: Server flow

trans-unit.source: Server flow means the client application relies on the gateway to communicate with the identity provider to initiate login.
trans-unit.target: Server flow means the client application relies on the gateway to communicate with the identity provider to initiate login.

trans-unit.source: The client browser goes to a gateway URL, and the gateway redirects the request to the identity provider's login page.
trans-unit.target: The client browser goes to a gateway URL, and the gateway redirects the request to the identity provider's login page.

trans-unit.source: After the user logs in, the gateway gets the identity provider's token, creates the Zumo token, and sends the Zumo token to the client.
trans-unit.target: After the user logs in, the gateway gets the identity provider's token, creates the Zumo token, and sends the Zumo token to the client.

trans-unit.source: Subsequent interaction between the client application and protected API apps or mobile apps is handled the same as for client flow: the client provides the Zumo token in HTTP requests.
trans-unit.target: Subsequent interaction between the client application and protected API apps or mobile apps is handled the same as for client flow: the client provides the Zumo token in HTTP requests.

trans-unit.source: How to choose between client flow and server flow
trans-unit.target: How to choose between client flow and server flow

trans-unit.source: The client flow is typically the best choice if the identity provider that you want to use has an SDK for the client platform that you want to support.
trans-unit.target: The client flow is typically the best choice if the identity provider that you want to use has an SDK for the client platform that you want to support.

trans-unit.source: Client flow provides the best user experience because it reduces the number of times the user has to enter credentials.
trans-unit.target: Client flow provides the best user experience because it reduces the number of times the user has to enter credentials.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your user has an android device, they probably have a Google account associated with their device, so if they can use that account without having to re-enter their user name and password, that makes for a better user experience.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your user has an android device, they probably have a Google account associated with their device, so if they can use that account without having to re-enter their user name and password, that makes for a better user experience.

trans-unit.source: Same thing with a Facebook account in an Android, iOS, or Windows Phone device, or a Microsoft account on a Windows desktop or Windows Phone.
trans-unit.target: Same thing with a Facebook account in an Android, iOS, or Windows Phone device, or a Microsoft account on a Windows desktop or Windows Phone.

trans-unit.source: In other scenarios the server flow may be a better choice:
trans-unit.target: In other scenarios the server flow may be a better choice:

trans-unit.source: There is no native client SDK for the identity provider and client platform you want to support.
trans-unit.target: There is no native client SDK for the identity provider and client platform you want to support.

trans-unit.source: You want to get something into production quickly and improve the user experience as time permits later.
trans-unit.target: You want to get something into production quickly and improve the user experience as time permits later.

trans-unit.source: The server flow lets Azure App Service do more of the authentication work, which minimizes the amount of development and testing you have to do.
trans-unit.target: The server flow lets Azure App Service do more of the authentication work, which minimizes the amount of development and testing you have to do.

trans-unit.source: On-behalf-of outgoing calls to SaaS platforms
trans-unit.target: On-behalf-of outgoing calls to SaaS platforms

trans-unit.source: You can write code to make outgoing calls to Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) platforms on behalf of a logged-in user or you can use a [connector API app](../app-service-mobile/app-service-logic-what-are-biztalk-api-apps.md).
trans-unit.target: You can write code to make outgoing calls to Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) platforms on behalf of a logged-in user or you can use a [connector API app](../app-service-mobile/app-service-logic-what-are-biztalk-api-apps.md).

trans-unit.source: For example, to post a tweet from the user's Twitter account you can use [a Twitter SDK](https://dev.twitter.com/overview/api/twitter-libraries), or provision a [Twitter connector](../app-service-mobile/app-service-logic-connector-twitter.md) in your Azure subscription and call that.
trans-unit.target: For example, to post a tweet from the user's Twitter account you can use [a Twitter SDK](https://dev.twitter.com/overview/api/twitter-libraries), or provision a [Twitter connector](../app-service-mobile/app-service-logic-connector-twitter.md) in your Azure subscription and call that.

trans-unit.source: This section is about accessing a SaaS platform from code that runs in an API app or mobile app.
trans-unit.target: This section is about accessing a SaaS platform from code that runs in an API app or mobile app.

trans-unit.source: Using the identity provider token
trans-unit.target: Using the identity provider token

trans-unit.source: The gateway maintains a *token store* in which it associates a Zumo token with one or more identity provider access tokens and refresh tokens.
trans-unit.target: The gateway maintains a *token store* in which it associates a Zumo token with one or more identity provider access tokens and refresh tokens.

trans-unit.source: When an HTTP request with a valid Zumo token is received, the gateway knows which identity provider tokens pertain to that user.
trans-unit.target: When an HTTP request with a valid Zumo token is received, the gateway knows which identity provider tokens pertain to that user.

trans-unit.source: When the code running in your API app or mobile app needs to make a call to a protected resource on behalf of the logged-on user, it can retrieve and use the identity provider's token from the gateway's token store, as shown in the following diagram.
trans-unit.target: When the code running in your API app or mobile app needs to make a call to a protected resource on behalf of the logged-on user, it can retrieve and use the identity provider's token from the gateway's token store, as shown in the following diagram.

trans-unit.source: The diagram assumes that the client has already authenticated with the gateway and has the Zumo token.
trans-unit.target: The diagram assumes that the client has already authenticated with the gateway and has the Zumo token.

trans-unit.source: For example, suppose the identity provider is Azure Active Directory (AAD), and your API app wants to use the AAD access token to call the AAD Graph API or request access to a SharePoint site that the user has permissions for.
trans-unit.target: For example, suppose the identity provider is Azure Active Directory (AAD), and your API app wants to use the AAD access token to call the AAD Graph API or request access to a SharePoint site that the user has permissions for.

trans-unit.source: You can send a request to the gateway to retrieve the AAD token, then use the AAD token to call the Graph API or to get an access token for the SharePoint site.
trans-unit.target: You can send a request to the gateway to retrieve the AAD token, then use the AAD token to call the Graph API or to get an access token for the SharePoint site.

trans-unit.target: Getting user consent to access other resources

trans-unit.target: The gateway also has built-in features for getting user consent when you want to access resources secured by a provider other than the original identity provider.

trans-unit.source: For example, for a user who signs in using Azure Active Directory, you might want to access files in the user's Dropbox account.
trans-unit.target: For example, for a user who signs in using Azure Active Directory, you might want to access files in the user's Dropbox account.

trans-unit.source: Alternative authentication methods
trans-unit.target: Alternative authentication methods

trans-unit.source: If the gateway authentication services don't meet the needs of your app, you can handle authentication yourself, or use the Azure API Management service.
trans-unit.target: If the gateway authentication services don't meet the needs of your app, you can handle authentication yourself, or use the Azure API Management service.

trans-unit.source: Do-it-yourself authentication
trans-unit.target: Do-it-yourself authentication

trans-unit.source: You can run an authentication framework such as [ASP.NET Identity](http://www.asp.net/identity) or [Thinktecture](http://www.thinktecture.com/identityAndAccessControl) on Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can run an authentication framework such as [ASP.NET Identity](http://www.asp.net/identity) or [Thinktecture](http://www.thinktecture.com/identityAndAccessControl) on Azure.

trans-unit.source: This gives you control over how everything works, but you also have to spend more time developing and testing authentication functionality.
trans-unit.target: This gives you control over how everything works, but you also have to spend more time developing and testing authentication functionality.

trans-unit.source: Also, if you have multiple apps to protect with multiple redirect URLs, you have to configure multiple client IDs and client secrets with third-party authentication providers such as Facebook, Google, and Twitter.
trans-unit.target: Also, if you have multiple apps to protect with multiple redirect URLs, you have to configure multiple client IDs and client secrets with third-party authentication providers such as Facebook, Google, and Twitter.

trans-unit.source: At present App Service does not support using a do-it-yourself solution alongside gateway authentication, as is possible in [Mobile Services](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-get-started-custom-authentication.md).
trans-unit.target: At present App Service does not support using a do-it-yourself solution alongside gateway authentication, as is possible in [Mobile Services](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-get-started-custom-authentication.md).

trans-unit.target: Azure API Management

trans-unit.source: If you have existing APIs that you want to protect with authentication, you can do that with the Azure API Management service.
trans-unit.target: If you have existing APIs that you want to protect with authentication, you can do that with the Azure API Management service.
